awd_titl_txt: EAGER: ISN: Anticipatory Interdiction in Narco-Trafficking Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will promote progress in scientific understanding of illicit supply networks by providing insights into how processes designed to disrupt Central American cocaine trafficking networks influence citizen security in the region and in the US. Counterdrug interdiction efforts are designed primarily to seize or disrupt drug shipments between South American source zones and US markets, and remain a core commitment of US supply-side drug policy and national security strategy. In response to these efforts, trafficking networks have fragmented existing trafficking routes into new and more numerous locations, resulting in a geographically diverse drug trafficking space.  This research builds an interdisciplinary understanding of the structure and function of narco-trafficking networks and their co-evolution with interdiction efforts to investigate how different interdiction approaches might impact traffickers' spatial, organizational, and economic behavior. This research establishes new intellectual bridges between operations engineering, geographic, and criminological perspectives, leading to more comprehensive and spatially detailed insights needed to inform effective drug policy. This award supports outreach activities to increase public understanding about the current state of drug trafficking in Central America as a consequence of US drug policy. The accompanying education plan will push the boundaries of conventional graduate education to meet the emerging needs of illicit support network research to inform policy.

This research will investigate temporally and spatially adaptive behaviors of narco-trafficking networks in response to various interdiction strategies within the cocaine transit zone of Central America and associated maritime areas. An integrated agent-based model that includes operational elements will be used to assess how the spatial and structural relationships of cocaine flows and prices along trafficking routes change in response to alternative interdiction strategies. This research represents a new paradigm in which trafficker-interdiction interactions are conceived of as a complex adaptive system and modeled as a co-evolutionary phenomenon. The integrated models will test hypotheses about the factors that explain the location and extent of emerging trafficking nodes in an expanding transit zone. The models will be parameterized with a novel application of data from the Consolidated Counterdrug Database (CCDB). Using a criminological lens, we will map the vulnerability of spaces in the so-called "transit zone" to enable a holistic analysis of the environmental and operational aspects of locations of new narco-trafficking activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The United States' (US) 'War on Drugs has been ongoing for over 40 years, while at the same time the production and distribution of cocaine has reached new highs over the last decade. The 'supply side' strategy (i.e., disrupting and seizing cocaine shipments before they reach the US) to combat cocaine consumption in the US has demonstrably failed, yet counterdrug interdiction remains core to US drug policy. This project addressed this apparent disconnect by combining advanced computational modeling approaches, ethnographic insights, and criminological theory to investigate the spatial adaptive behaviors of cocaine- or 'narco'-trafficking networks in response to various counterdrug interdiction strategies within the cocaine transit zone of Central America and associated maritime areas. Insights gained through collaboration with the Joint Inter-Agency Task Force- South (JIATF-S) - the organization charged with coordinating counterdrug interdiction efforts in the study region - were integrated into the formulation and implementation of a 'family of interdiction models' representing alternative interdiction strategies. The collaboration enabled a more realistic representation of counterdrug interdiction operations than has been previously achieved. The resulting interdiction model was coupled with an innovative simulation of narco-trafficking behavior to investigate the spatial dynamics of their resilience as the result of co-evolution with counterdrug interdiction operations. A number of theoretical, empirical, and methodological advances emerged from this integrative approach.

A main goal of the project was to increase public understanding about the current state of drug trafficking in Central America as a consequence of U.S. transit zone interdiction policy. This was accomplished through a range of dissemination, outreach, and education activities. The project resulted in the publication of nine peer-reviewed journal articles on topics including: quantifying the effects of interdiction pressure on the suitability of Central American landscapes for cocaine trafficking; methodological advances in coupling simulation and spatial optimization models; statistical modeling of the causal relationship between forest loss and narco-trafficking; and theoretical contributions to the comparative and empirical study of illicit supply networks. We also hosted a Reddit r/askscience Ask Me Anything (AMA) series event about our project findings to engage a broader and non-scientific audience. The AMA event received more than 2,700 votes and 124 comments. The project also directly supported the research training of two doctoral students, one Master?s student, and one undergraduate student. Findings from the project have also been integrated into a module on illicit economic activities and their impacts on land-use change in a cross-listed undergraduate/graduate course at the lead institution.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2023
Modified by: Nicholas Magliocca
